Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Building Infrastructure to Prevent Disasters like Hurricane Maria

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is an urgent need to understand the impacts of severe flooding and infrastructure damage on public health after natural disasters. One limitation to effective disaster response is easy and rapid access to diverse information about available resources, community resource needs, baseline and current environmental conditions. This project aims to expand access to environmental and drinking water quality disaster response and recovery data in a publicly available format using a widely used collaborative online sharing platform named HydroShare. Curating a central repository of assembled data has the potential to greatly facilitate coordinated disaster responses of all types, and improve the monitoring of the recovery process. The project team will prototype this system with an assessment of drinking water, environment, and public health concerns unique to Puerto Rico in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. By working directly with public water utilities, the project team intends to characterize and map the severity of impaired water resources and distribution systems in Puerto Rico, inform communities about how to protect themselves against hazards specific to their water, and to contribute to rebuilding so the nation is better prepared for future hurricanes. Developing cyber and social infrastructure to understand the dynamics of drinking water contamination after natural disasters will improve disaster preparedness and response, and contribute to efforts across the nation and the world to build for a resilient future.

Recovery efforts from natural disasters can be more efficient with data-driven information on current needs and future risks. This project aims to advance open-source software infrastructure to support scientific investigation and data-driven decision making with a prototype system using a water quality assessment developed to investigate post-Hurricane Maria drinking water contamination in Puerto Rico. The widespread disruption of water treatment processes and uncertain drinking water quality within distribution systems in Puerto Rico poses risk to human health. However, there is no existing digital infrastructure to scientifically determine the impacts of the hurricane to inform a response to the crisis. After every natural disaster, including hurricane Maria, elementary questions on how to provide high quality water supplies and support basic human health are difficult to answer. This project will archive and make accessible data on environmental variables unique to Puerto Rico and Hurricane Maria, damage caused by the storm, and will begin to address time sensitive needs of citizens. By working directly with drinking water utilities to collect samples of biological and inorganic drinking water quality, this project aims to generate understanding and awareness of the degree to which drinking water systems were impacted by Hurricane Maria and the status of drinking water infrastructure and emergency recovery in Puerto Rico after the storm. The goal of this project is to advance understanding of how the severity of a hazard to human health (e.g., no access to safe culinary water) is related to the sophistication, connectivity, and operations of the physical and related digital infrastructure systems. By rapidly collecting data in the early stages of recovery, the team plans to test the design of an integrated cyberinfrastructure system to increase the accessibility of environmental and health data for understanding the impacts from hurricane-related natural disasters. The team will test and stress the CUAHSI HydroShare data publication mechanisms and capabilities to (1) assess the spatial and temporal presence of waterborne pathogens in public water systems impacted by a natural disaster, (2) demonstrate usability of HydroShare as a clearinghouse to centralize selected datasets related to Hurricane Maria, and (3) develop a prototype cyberinfrastructure to assess environmental conditions and public health impacted by natural disasters. By rapidly collecting data in the early stages of recovery, The team plans to test the design of an integrated cyberinfrastructure system to increase the accessibility of environmental and health data for understanding the impacts from hurricane-related natural disasters. This work will develop a prototype of a software infrastructure system to advance understanding of how data-driven information can reduce the impacts of natural disaster and serve as a platform for future research. The project thus serves to not only document post-disaster conditions, but develops a process to track the impact of recovery over time, as monitored through health, power availability and water quality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On September 20, 2017, Hurricane Maria made landfall in Puerto Rico as a Category 4 storm.  With sustained winds of 155 miles per hour and three times the rainfall recorded for Hurricane Harvey in Houston earlier in 2017, Hurricane Maria decimated Puerto Rico’s infrastructure. An estimated 3.1 million people were without power or access to clean water. In this collaborative Rapid Research (RAPID) project, our team at Virginia Tech focused on collecting data related to water quality in impacted watersheds and drinking water systems. The data collected served to inform development and advancement of cyberinfrastructure to support scientific investigation and data-driven decision-making following future natural disasters.

Many drinking water treatment systems across the island experienced a temporary lapse in treatment due to damage to the infrastructure caused by the hurricane. Major impediments included lack of electricity, damage to solar-power generators powering the treatment systems, clogging of filter media due to higher sediment loads, surges in surface water flow rates, or physical damage requiring repair. Lack of access (physical and financial) to appropriate equipment was also a major barrier to recovery.  Thus, each unregulated drinking water system faced unique challenges delivering safe drinking water to consumers.

Widespread flooding that occurred during Hurricane Maria also caused at least one-third of the island’s 55 wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) to become temporarily, allowing raw sewage to be discharged directly into the environment. Urban and rural flooding can severely alter microbial landscapes and spike the level of fecal pathogens as well as antibiotic resistant organisms and antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs). Such flooding also severely compromises the raw source water used for drinking water and could potentially contaminate drinking water systems.

Virginia Tech coordinated with the Center for Environmental Education, Conservation and Research (CECIA) at the Inter American University of Puerto Rico to conduct field sampling and provide baseline information for assessing public health concerns related to drinking water supplies following Hurricane Maria. We sampled raw water sources, treated drinking water, and distributed tap water of six rural, small, non-regulated community water systems, as well as one larger surface water Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) municipality. Each system had unique geography, source water, and recovery resources available that required tailor made solutions. For example, water treatments in each community varied from chlorination of surface or groundwater to slow sand biofiltration at varying scales. As would be expected, systems that relied on groundwater supplies had fewer incidences of detection of waterborne pathogen DNA markers. This portion of the research advanced knowledge regarding the effects of hurricanes and other extreme flooding events on pathogen propagation in rural water systems.

Concordant with the drinking water sampling, we surveyed water and sediment samples along three watersheds that represented varying degrees of urbanization to evaluate ARGs, metals, and microbial communities and their relationship to pristine, residentially-impacted, and WWTP effluent sites in the wake of the hurricane. We found that key indicator genes for anthropogenic sources of antibiotic resistance increased from pristine to more urban-, or residentially- and/or commercially-impacted sites.    

The results of the water quality survey were incorporated into a Collaborative RAPID Digital Infrastructure Design workshop to determine the needs and barriers of public health researchers in the aftermath of hurricane disasters. The workshop incorporated government officials, academic, and public utility hurricane data stakeholders, as well as rural community water system data stakeholders. Our collaborators then used information from workshops and qualitative interviews to design scientific cyberinfrastructure that integrates existing hardware/software platforms to archive and disseminate water resources data decision makers. Overall, the Virginia Tech-led portion of this RAPID effort demonstrated intellectual merit by providing valuable baseline information for assessing concerns to public health related to drinking water during active recovery of a major storm. This work will also have broader impacts that benefit society, particularly the Puerto Rican communities serviced by this study, by informing decisions regarding source selection and treatment application to sustain high quality drinking water during storm recovery. The overall products are expected to have broader impacts that benefit society into the future by providing a resource and point of reference for recovery from future storms, particularly those affecting rural populations.  The project also provided field experience for 2 undergraduate, 3 graduate, and four post-doctoral researchers, who will add to the workforce of individuals capable of mobilizing to support future storm research and recovery efforts.
